titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Divinity School Reference Collection, 1926-ongoing
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Archives Staff; machine-readable finding aid created by: Sherrie Bowser

change.item: Converted from dtd to schema and transformed with AT-import-fixer.xsl

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Founded in 1926 as the first of the university's graduate professional schools, the Divinity School attracts students from around the nation and several different countries. One of 13 seminaries founded and supported by the United Methodist Church, the school has from its beginnings been ecumenical in aspiration, teaching, and practice. With many diverse theological perspectives, students find common ground through immersion in Scripture and the church's tradition for addressing the challenges of faith in today's world. Collection contains subject files relating to the Divinity School at Duke University. Some major topics include admissions, sermons, symposiums, continuing education, field education, student groups, and other topics. Video cassettes and audio cassettes are also present in the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: Copyright for Official University records is held by Duke University; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Divinity School Reference Collection, Duke University Archives, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Divinity School Reference Collection was compiled from a variety of sources by the University Archives for use in reference and research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions were merged into one collection, described in this finding aid.
